questions.text: Who was the Greek goddess of wisdom and warfare?
questions.explanation: Athena was the goddess of wisdom, warfare, and handicrafts. She sprang fully grown from Zeus's head.

questions.text: What was the name of the winged horse in Greek mythology?
questions.explanation: Pegasus was the immortal winged horse that sprang from Medusa's blood when Perseus beheaded her.

questions.text: Which hero was forced to complete 12 labors?
questions.explanation: Hercules (Heracles) was forced to complete 12 labors as penance for killing his family in a fit of madness induced by Hera.

questions.text: Who was the god of the sea?
questions.explanation: Poseidon was the god of the sea, earthquakes, and horses. He wielded a trident as his weapon.

questions.text: What creature had the head of a bull and the body of a man?
questions.explanation: The Minotaur was a creature with a bull's head and man's body, kept in the labyrinth of Crete and slain by Theseus.

questions.text: Who was the goddess of love and beauty?
questions.explanation: Aphrodite was the goddess of love, beauty, and desire. According to legend, she was born from sea foam.

questions.text: What did Pandora release when she opened her box?
questions.explanation: Pandora released all the evils into the world, with only Hope remaining in the box.

questions.text: Who was the messenger god with winged sandals?
questions.explanation: Hermes was the messenger of the gods, known for his winged sandals and caduceus staff.

questions.text: What was the name of Hades' three-headed dog?
questions.explanation: Cerberus was the three-headed dog that guarded the gates of the Underworld, preventing the dead from leaving.

questions.text: Who turned everything he touched into gold?
questions.explanation: King Midas was granted the 'golden touch' by Dionysus, which became a curse when he couldn't eat or drink.

questions.text: Which goddess was married to Zeus?
questions.explanation: Hera was Zeus's wife and the goddess of marriage and family, though their marriage was often troubled by Zeus's infidelities.

questions.text: What was the home of the Greek gods?
questions.explanation: Mount Olympus was believed to be the home of the twelve Olympian gods, led by Zeus.

questions.text: Who flew too close to the sun with wax wings?
questions.explanation: Icarus flew too close to the sun despite his father Daedalus's warnings, melting the wax in his wings and falling to his death.

questions.text: Which hero killed the Gorgon Medusa?
questions.explanation: Perseus beheaded Medusa using a mirrored shield to avoid her petrifying gaze.

questions.text: What was the prize Jason sought with the Argonauts?
questions.explanation: Jason and the Argonauts embarked on a quest to retrieve the Golden Fleece from Colchis.

questions.text: Who was the god of wine and revelry?
questions.explanation: Dionysus (Bacchus in Roman mythology) was the god of wine, festivity, and theater.

questions.text: What was Achilles' only vulnerable spot?
questions.explanation: Achilles' heel was his only vulnerable point, where his mother held him when dipping him in the River Styx.

questions.text: Who was the goddess of the hunt?
questions.explanation: Artemis was the goddess of the hunt, wilderness, and moon, twin sister of Apollo.

questions.text: What creature was half-man, half-horse?
questions.explanation: Centaurs were creatures with the upper body of a human and the lower body of a horse.

questions.text: Who was the Titan who gave fire to humanity?
questions.explanation: Prometheus stole fire from the gods and gave it to humanity, for which Zeus punished him by chaining him to a rock.

questions.text: What was the name of Odysseus's wife who waited for him?
questions.explanation: Penelope waited faithfully for 20 years for Odysseus to return from the Trojan War and his subsequent journey.

questions.text: Who was condemned to roll a boulder up a hill for eternity?
questions.explanation: Sisyphus was punished in Tartarus by being forced to roll a boulder uphill, only to watch it roll back down forever.

questions.text: What was the name of the winged goddess of victory?
questions.explanation: Nike was the goddess of victory, often depicted with wings. The modern athletic brand is named after her.

questions.text: Who was the god of war?
questions.explanation: Ares was the god of war, violence, and bloodshed, though he was not as favored as Athena, goddess of strategic warfare.

questions.text: What multi-headed serpent did Hercules fight?
questions.explanation: The Lernaean Hydra was a serpent-like monster with multiple heads that grew back when cut off. It was Hercules' second labor.

questions.text: Who was the god of the sun and music?
questions.explanation: Apollo was the god of the sun, music, poetry, prophecy, and healing. He was the twin brother of Artemis.

questions.text: What was the name of the nymphs who were Odysseus's temptresses?
questions.explanation: The Sirens were dangerous creatures who lured sailors with their enchanting music and voices to shipwreck on their island.

questions.text: Who was the blacksmith god?
questions.explanation: Hephaestus was the god of fire, metalworking, and crafts. He forged weapons and armor for the gods.

questions.text: What creature did Theseus slay in the labyrinth?
questions.explanation: Theseus entered the labyrinth of Crete and killed the Minotaur, using Ariadne's thread to find his way out.

questions.text: Who was the goddess of agriculture and harvest?
questions.explanation: Demeter was the goddess of agriculture, grain, and the harvest. Her daughter was Persephone.

questions.text: What was the River of the Underworld called?
questions.explanation: The River Styx separated the world of the living from the dead. The gods swore their most binding oaths upon it.

questions.text: Who opened a box releasing all evils into the world?
questions.explanation: Pandora, the first woman created by the gods, opened a jar (often mistranslated as 'box') releasing all evils, keeping only Hope inside.

questions.text: Who was the Titan forced to hold up the sky?
questions.explanation: Atlas was condemned by Zeus to hold up the celestial heavens for eternity after the Titanomachy.

questions.text: What was the name of Hades' wife?
questions.explanation: Persephone was abducted by Hades to be his queen in the Underworld, causing her mother Demeter to create winter.

questions.text: Who was the mortal woman loved by Zeus who was turned into a cow?
questions.explanation: Zeus transformed Io into a cow to hide her from Hera's jealousy, but Hera sent a gadfly to torment her.

questions.text: What golden object caused the Trojan War?
questions.explanation: The Apple of Discord, inscribed 'for the fairest,' was thrown by Eris and led to the judgment of Paris, sparking the Trojan War.

questions.text: Who was the leader of the Greek forces at Troy?
questions.explanation: Agamemnon, king of Mycenae, led the Greek forces during the Trojan War.

questions.text: What creature had the head of a lion, body of a goat, and tail of a serpent?
questions.explanation: The Chimera was a fire-breathing hybrid monster slain by Bellerophon riding Pegasus.

questions.text: Who fell in love with his own reflection?
questions.explanation: Narcissus fell in love with his own reflection in a pool and wasted away, transforming into the narcissus flower.

questions.text: What was the name of the nine goddesses of the arts?
questions.explanation: The nine Muses were goddesses who presided over the arts and sciences, inspiring artists and thinkers.

questions.text: Who was the Greek hero known for his cunning and the Trojan Horse?
questions.explanation: Odysseus conceived the plan of the Trojan Horse, which led to the fall of Troy.

questions.text: What were the three Furies goddesses of?
questions.explanation: The Furies (Erinyes) were goddesses of vengeance who punished crimes, especially those against family.

questions.text: Who was the goddess of the hearth and home?
questions.explanation: Hestia was the virgin goddess of the hearth, home, and family. She was the first-born child of Cronus and Rhea.

questions.text: What creature posed riddles to travelers and ate those who couldn't answer?
questions.explanation: The Sphinx of Thebes posed a riddle to travelers and devoured those who failed. Oedipus solved it, causing the Sphinx to destroy itself.

questions.text: Who was the god of dreams?
questions.explanation: Morpheus was the god of dreams, able to take any human form and appear in dreams.

questions.text: What was the name of Odysseus's son?
questions.explanation: Telemachus was the son of Odysseus and Penelope, who went searching for his father during the Odyssey.

questions.text: Who was the primordial goddess of Earth?
questions.explanation: Gaia was the personification of Earth and the ancestral mother of all life in Greek mythology.

questions.text: What was the food of the gods that granted immortality?
questions.explanation: Ambrosia was the food of the gods that granted immortality, while nectar was their drink.

questions.text: Who was the twin sister of Apollo?
questions.explanation: Artemis was Apollo's twin sister, born to Zeus and Leto on the island of Delos.

questions.text: What was the labyrinth on Crete built to contain?
questions.explanation: King Minos commissioned Daedalus to build the labyrinth to contain the Minotaur, a creature born from his wife and a bull.
